awd_titl_txt: CRII: SaTC: Creating and Managing Structurally-Morphing IT Systems - Moving Targets
awd_abstract_narration:
Current information technology (IT) systems are relatively static from a configuration perspective and give adversaries the valuable advantage of time for breaching them. A new concept, called Moving Target Defense or MTD, dynamically reconfigures systems to increase uncertainty and complexity for attackers, reduce their window of opportunity, and raise the costs of their reconnaissance and attack endeavors. All of these contribute towards increased security. Unfortunately, current moving target defense approaches tend to address only individual aspects or components of an IT system and not holistically the entire system. While such efforts are important building-blocks, how a large complex system can be dynamically reconfigured and adapted remains an open research problem.  This project investigates the feasibility and challenges related to adopting moving target defense for creating and managing structurally morphing IT systems in order to better protect them. It also provides opportunities for curriculum enhancement via integrating research results in cyber defense courses, training students at different levels and from under-represented groups and informing the security research community about opportunities and impediments to enterprise system defenses via moving target defense.

The project develops a comprehensive framework/platform for creating and managing structurally changing IT systems. The framework consists of several components: a methodology to abstract the functionality and structure of enterprise systems into a high-level multi-layered model, a compiler that converts the abstract requirements into an actual system, and a moving target defense strategy generator to assist and proactively evaluate the cost of various combinations of system changes against the security benefits achieved and performance overheads incurred. The framework is prototyped leveraging readily available virtualized environments, containerization techniques and configuration management tools. Vital component operations belonging to the moving target defense infrastructure are protected using the notion of hardware supported security enclaves to further enhance the security of the framework.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Moving target defense (MTD) mechanisms, built on the premise of dynamically changing a system's configuration to increase the cost of attack on adversaries, have been introduced as a game changer in cybersecurity. Such mechanisms have the potential to become the security solution of choice for next generation, highly-reconfigurable information technology (IT) systems. Indeed, the ease-of-programmability and advanced virtualization options of wired and wireless IT systems present unique opportunities for fortifying these with MTD. However, despite this positive outlook, to date, most existing MTD solutions have been restricted to isolated experiments often reliant on qualitative studies and generally focused on a limited number of MTD types. Without discounting these existing efforts, there undoubtedly is a need to introduce new MTD solutions tailored to the unique properties of flexible IT systems and grounded on a quantifiable and robust mathematical basis. 


In short, this project was geared towards addressing this need. Specifically, the project was a collaborative effort and focused on developing effective MTD solutions that address the following challenges: 1) Optimizing heterogeneous MTD approaches while accounting for their compatibility, 2) Developing technology-agnostic MTD strategies that can be deployed in different IT systems, 3) Optimizing security measures without jeopardizing normal network operations, 4) Fast dynamics of reconfigurable IT systems, and 5) Enabling MTD mechanisms in a highly resource-constrained environment. 
The project adopted a multi-faceted effort involving approaches from computer science and electrical engineering that enabled the researchers to adapt to new challenges. For instance, the project explored  different types of environments starting with traditional enterprise networks, to power systems, and resource-constrained setups. The research team assessed the impact of dynamic changes in these environments and attempted to design customizable frameworks to turn these environments into moving targets for adversaries. The ultimate objective focused on turning the tables on attackers by creating an oblivious defense where attackers need to operate under significant constraints on time and resources. The research findings were validated by different communities and resulted in multiple peer-reviewed publications in two cybersecurity conferences, one Communication Society conference, one Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE) journal, and three power systems conferences. 


All in all, the project trained three graduate students, involved multiple undergraduate students, and brought together collaborators from industry and academia. The perspectives and backgrounds of the involved researchers were diverse and included various underrepresented groups such as Native-American, African-American, Asian-American, and female researchers.
